title: Barry Lyndon is a piece of art and an unforgettable experience, an achievement in cinematography, but is it entertaining? Not really, yet it doesn't need to be
content: What's the first thing I thought about before watching Barry Lyndon? The gorgeous and perfect cinematography where every frame is like a painting, that's about what I knew about it before my friend at film studies told me more about it. The scale of this film, the vision Stanley Kubrick had for it, if you can call something a masterpiece then this is it. I rate this film high because of it being an art film, the pacing is extremely slow and the story doesn't have that extra amount of heart poured into it, coming out as a film which lacks real emotion at times. With that said, I think if you go into this film knowing it's slow paced and you have the energy to sit down to watch it, I'm sure you'll love it. I did! It's an achievement in cinema in a way, Kubrick directed a film with frames which will be remembered for decades more and possibly centuries. Every frame is like a painting, it's actually based on William Hogarth paintings. The dialogue and what happens in the scenes is not as memorable, as it's the visual storytelling which is perfect here. Stanley Kubrick adapted and told a fascinating story, a truly great one.An Irish rogue wins the heart of a rich widow and assumes her dead husband's aristocratic position in 18th-century England.The actors, main to supporting and even smaller roles. There are so many performances which are just perfect and something a critic wrote which I could only agree on, "makes you realise that the most undervalued aspect of Kubrick's genius could well be his way with actors.", and that couldn't be more true. From how Stanley Kubrick directed the actors to how he chose them, these actors probably researched the time period as well. Every single detail in their performances is just perfect. Ryan O'Neal portrays the title character with such perfection.The film's cinematography was overseen by director of photography John Alcott (who won an Oscar for his work), and is particularly noted for the technical innovations that made some of its most spectacular images possible. To achieve photography without electric lighting, they shot it with candlelight which had to be a difficult thing to do. What we got was something truly mesmerizing, beautiful and simply perfect. There's much to say about the cinematography, the length Stanley Kubrick and John Alcott went to create each shot. The special ultra-fast lenses which made it possible to shoot in natural light (candle lit rooms for example), then we have the camera angles used; long double shot, with a slow backwards zoom. If a scene is shot with a close up or longer, it zoomed out which made us see everything like a painting and easier to notice the attention to detail which was put into the film. The mise-en-scene is truly perfect in Barry Lyndon, the cinematography is groundbreaking. The musical score is brilliant and important for the film's many shots which resembles paintings, making us feel even more immersed in the time period, and making it more dramatic. I've said how the direction and cinematography are brilliant, let me get into the writing; Kubrick based his adapted screenplay on William Makepeace Thackeray's The Luck of Barry Lyndon, but made a couple of changes to it, all welcomed changes I would guess (as I haven't read the novel). There's nothing wrong about the writing, the dialogue and plot are spectacular, its slow pacing hurts the plot though along with the over-reliance of the voiceover. This makes the film not that entertaining, but that's quite alright. I went into this film knowing it would be a piece of art, I wasn't disappointed. It's a brilliant film with some terrific and nicely executed themes; Fate and destiny, but also father and son. As Roger Ebert says, "He is a man to whom things happen." Barry just can't escape his fate, as what happens to him happens for a reason, his destiny. Barry Lyndon received seven nominations at the 48th Academy Awards, including Best Picture, winning four for Best Scoring: Original Song Score and Adaptation or Scoring: Adaptation, Best Cinematography, Best Art Direction, and Best Costume Design. In the 2022 Sight & Sound Greatest Films of All Time poll, Barry Lyndon placed 12th in the directors' poll and 45th in the critics' poll.Roger Ebert gave the film three and a half stars out of four and wrote that it "is almost aggressive in its cool detachment. It defies us to care, it forces us to remain detached about its stately elegance." He added, "This must be one of the most beautiful films ever made." He added the film to his 'Great Movies' list on 9 September 2009 and increased his original rating from three and a half stars to four, writing, "Stanley Kubrick's Barry Lyndon, received indifferently in 1975, has grown in stature in the years since and is now widely regarded as one of the master's best. It is certainly in every frame a Kubrick film: technically awesome, emotionally distant, remorseless in its doubt of human goodness." Barry Lyndon, a film worthy to be called one of the finest and best films, worthy of all its praise. If you got the time, you can easily pause whenever and look at the frames, many if not all looks brilliant. This film is truly mesmerizing and spectacular.

title: Riveting and entertaining
content: If you're not planning to watch this movie because it's a three hour lon period piece, make no mistake, this is one of the most entertaining and emotional movies out there.

title: Opulent, beautiful - paintings come to life; Kubricks often overlooked masterpiece.
content:
Save to say - I avoided watching this wonderful 3 hour long epos for many years, because 2001 or the Shining seemed more thrilling. What made me finally watch it was the art of KEN ADAMS, the brilliant production designer for many Kubrick films (2001!) and this was one of the rare films where he had to use sets on location. And got an Oscar for it. So - time to watch this, jeez!I must say: I was overwhelmed by the raw power of the images. Old dutch paintings came to life and each detail was thought through. The film lives through his brilliant actors, but also the slow zoom out, the image compositions, the (mostly natural (or inspired by natural light situations...) light and the intense making process impressed me for sure. --- Man, did you know they used a NASA camera lens that was 0.7 aperture due to Kubricks idea of filming interior scenes with candle light? Or that they had to use camera light filters excessively because they traveled 8 months through France, Germany and Ireland to get these amazing, wide angle painting like shots and the weather kept changing every minute? That impressed me a lot... because it looks so easily done, but hell yes, to make such a masterpiece, you need madness and true passion (Kubrick had it!).
He caused Ken Adam to have some break downs and for sure, it did not seem to be easy to work with Kubrick. But all the locations they chose for the period piece, all the landscapes - they are on point. Adam impresses not only in studio, but on location, big time.The film impresses BECAUSE it tries to give us a (still altered, still artificial, yep...!) glimpse into the 17th century: war, love, monarchy and the fate of a normal man. It feels oddly real and oddly relatable, not only because of the story, but how it is told visually. I was visually pleased throughout the whole movie and am grateful that I finally watched it. It is for sure one of my favorite Kubrick films, because it tells the story of fate and mankind - this time set back few centuries before our time (not in the future like 2001), but asks similar questions... what is fate and what is coincidence? And are we all equal?
Yes - we are: in life, in death, in our human needs.WONDERFUL masterpiece, can only recommend watching it.PS: Can't stop thinking that it inspired also the film THE FAVORITE (2019), as it works sometimes with similar tones and techniques... and a similar story.

title: A period film like no other . . .
content: Stanley Kubrick's Barry Lyndon is a period film like no other, a slow yet utterly mesmerising tale of an Irish upstart whose minor triumphs and major calamities take in the Seven Years' War, the gambling houses of Europe and marriage into the aristocracy. Filmed over 18 tumultuous months without a real script, it stars Ryan O'Neal as well as former model Marisa Berenson, whose limited acting ability is in fact a strength rather than a weakness as the characters become mere figures in a Hogarth-like canvas. Flesh and blood is provided by the likes of Leonard Rossiter and, best of all, Leon Vitali as O'Neal's maltreated stepson. The film features a definitive duel scene (perhaps second only to that in The Duellists), sly narration from Michael Hordern, splendid music ranging from Handel to Schubert and sublime backdrops courtesy of Castle Howard and Blenheim. Give it time, adjust to the pace and enjoy Kubrick's grandest gamble and greatest film.

title: The Story of a Strange Diversion Taken in the Life of One Redmond Barry
content: Barry Lyndon is a film that doesn't follow the life of Redmond Barry but a years-long diversion his life takes which is catalyzed by a, seemingly, unimportant quarrel which leads to major consequences.With this film, Kubrick managed to bring to life a 19th century novel in the best possible way. From the narration, the way the characters behave, the costumes, the soundtrack, and even the use of natural, non-electric lighting make this film feel incredibly authentic.Barry Lyndon thrusts the viewer into this world as you follow Redmond through his life adventures going from a naive Irish farm boy to returning a more broken man. Films like this make for great cinema as following the lives of people and how small instances of something happening can lead to much bigger things later on.This is a character driven story, and as a result some might not find it particularly interesting seeing as how there's no real plot to speak of in the same many might be used to. Redmond is living his life and, in the course of his life and his decisions, things happen as a consequence of them, and thus the story feeds itself. The film doesn't really have so much a conclusion as it simply ends, but since it only follows a particular period of this character's life, ending it any other way aside from with his death, would ruin the feeling of authenticity.This film probably isn't for everybody, especially for those who are more accustomed to plot-driven films. But just like with an old, 19th century novel, if one is willing to remove themselves from what they expect and go in and take this film for what it is one might find what makes this film so fascinating. It's not like Kubrick's other works, but it's still a great piece by him either way.

title: Barry Lyndon: 8.5/10
content: "Barry Lyndon" has been described as a novel without a hero, and it's true. The main character, Barry, is a man who is enveloped in selfishness and greed, and yet, the film manages to make me so engrossed in his journey through Europe and up the ranks of British society.Speaking of his journey, It was tremendously gorgeous. The beautiful natural landscape and Stanley Kubrick's direction of the whole thing really add to the film. Not only that, I also like the costumes, sets, and Ryan O'Neal's performance In The lead role.Overall, I'd say Barry Lyndon was worth the 3 runtime, and it is yet another great addition to Kubrick's filmography. 8.5/10.Lastly, all stated is just my opinion, and it's okay if you disagree.

title: Kubrick is God (end of discussion)
content: This movie needed to be seen the first showing of the first day it played: two weeks later, with scratches and dust on the print, the effect was not quite the same.  The perfection of the style of the cinematography, compositions that were a series of tableaux of period paintings, set the environment of the story like no movie had before (or has since).  The same critics who found this picture over-long and the performances wooden were some of the same people who waxed rhapsodic over 2001.  Though "wooden" is a calculated part of Kubrick's palette, 2001 is definitely the longer of the two pictures, in my opinion.  Critics of the day also found the narration to be "anti-dramatic", as in several cases throughout, the narrator announced what was about to be played out on the screen.  I found this device, as with Kubrick's other intentional effects in this picture, to be absolute perfection.  Viewers who were not brought up on Kubrick become very impatient with the worshipful tones some of us adopt when discussing his films.  What can I say?  He is the only director whose decisions I would never have the effrontery to question.

title: Solid Kubrick
content:
Stanley Kubrick is a clever director making various films that are thought provoking and very memorable films.Barry Lyndon is a different film of his , in fact I do not think any of Kubrick's movies are similar due to his variation of films which is a very good thing , but this film is different because it's set in the 1770's which is a very very old time but Mr Kubrick really depicted the 1770's really well and the way he did it are like , the marching theme and the suits that the people wear very accurately depicted and one of the best thing and possibly the best thing about this movie is how the shots are framed, each frame looks like a very pricy painting from the 1770's that can be sold today for millions , in this movie literally most of the shots were done like that , very very clever camera work and very amazing sets and dialogue and character development and design.The story itself is definitely pretty good the rise of Mr Barry and what he did to achieve all of what he got is so very well done by Mr Kubrick.Overall a pretty solid movie while not the best Kubrick it was definitely great
8/10.

title: choice of actor
content: I don't have much to add to the assessments made by the other reviewers except to say that Barry Lyndon is one of my favourite films. There is just one point about it that I'd like to comment on, and that is Kubrick's choice of Ryan O'Neal as the actor to play Barry. O'Neal was a good actor but he was not suitable for this part. Few Americans can play the role of a European well. Someone like Malcolm McDowell or Richard Harris or some other Irish or English actor would have been a much better choice. Kubrick may well have picked O'Neal as a draw for the movie-going public. Having said that the film is otherwise a brilliant creation.

title: THE MOST BEAUTIFUL FILM THAT I HAVE EVER SEEN
content: Legendary filmmaker Stanley Kubrick's masterpiece Barry Lyndon is the most beautiful film that I have ever seen. Every single frame is so gorgeous and beautifully photographed. The composition is indescribable in words or even sentences. The bgm is so gripping and beautiful that it will grab you mind hook you on the screen. All of this combined with incredible production design and amazing costume design makes this an all-perfect work of filmography.The story is about Redmond Barry a man who seems to be helpless in the beginning and went through certain hardships and finally became an opportunist and he reached at a position where he acquired great glory. As things changed, he also changed. Once a helpless innocent man became a man of cruelty and immorality. Finally, he got what he deserved. Vengeance paid off on him and lost everything he gained.This movie advocates the philosophy of change in life and also it says that nothing is permanent. One day the mortal coil will be lost. In afterlife there is no good and bad or rich and poor and everyone will be equal because everyone will be in the sleep from which they can't wake up. And this will happen to everybody no matter what.

title: BARRY LYNDON (1975) - 11/11/2019
content: A fabulous picaresque tale - satirical and tragic - in which we see Kubrick make every splendid shot look like an authentic 18th-century painting while using a cynical and essentially cold approach to recount a long series of barely connected episodes in our anti-hero's ill-fated life. Barry Lyndon is fantastic and amazingly helmed by Stanley Kubrick that boasts great performances and a revolutionary direction.Mitchell Bulfin

title: Like stepping into a painting
content: 'Barry Lyndon' isn't the first movie to come to mind when you think about Stanley Kubrick. But in a filmography of unique pictures this might be his most unique. Yes, the movie is rather long, but it has a certain flow to it that makes you forget the runtime. For three hours you see the story of a man who manages to gain everything he ever wanted and than, just as ruthlessly, lose it all.The viewer follows the endeavours of the Irish low born, Redmond Barry. He falls in love, but can't get the woman he desires. Forced to leave his home he joins the army. First as a soldier of the British army and than as a trusted pawn of the Prussian Army. By lack of a better word, luck befalls on him and he manages to obtain a title of nobility. A position, it turns out, he is unfit for. We see him mistreating his high born wife, fight with his stepson and squandering away almost all of his wife's fortune.'Barry Lyndon' is a three hour case study of an opportunistic man, ruthless and devious in getting what he wants, but who has no idea on how to keep it. Yet, we can't really dislike him for his dubious behaviour and we sympathize with him when things take a turn for the worse. He is no hero, but he isn't trying to be. He is just a human being.Then finally we arrive at the point that sets this movie apart from other films; the cinematography. Every shot seems to be constructed by the master as if it were a painting. Kubrick's greatest talent perhaps was making the highly artistic avant-garde accessible enough for the mainstream. Every bit of picturesque scenery creates the perfect atmosphere and gives the viewer the illusion that it was all carefully crafted by some of the finest painters throughout history. It might be the biggest achievement in cinematography ever put to film.Everything about this film screams art, and although quite long, can be one of the most unique experiences you will ever witness on screen. You just have to sit back and render yourself to the beautiful landscapes and structures Kubrick presents to you.

title: Epic of a Rogue
content: In the mid-to-late 1700's Europe, by the time Ryan O'Neal's BARRY LYNDON has traveled from his small hometown village in Ireland, then as a soldier through a war then a war-deserter and then a captured-deserter throughout several other countries, ninety-minutes have passed... the length of an average motion picture... and with so much literal ground covered, director Stanley Kubrick provided more an episodic than thrilling adventure since every location is its very own thematic vignette with a beginning, middle and end...Where in each, O'Neal's Barry... surrounding by picturesque landscapes intended as visual portrait/paintings framing each gorgeous, self-lighted interior and exterior shot... has to find a way to get his way, from selfish, boyish determination to keep the cousin he's smitten with unmarried, which is the first and perhaps best sequence also involving her would-be military finance Leonard Rossiter, providing a perfectly passive, cowardly counterbalance to O'Neal's intrepid Lyndon, whose last name's originally Redmond...Changed to Lyndon after marrying rich widow Marisa Berenson as Lady Honoria Lyndon, and, while several characters evoke the desperation in O'Neal's character... from a highwayman horse-thief to winning a boxing match with a much larger soldier... she brings out the outright scoundrel... underlined by her only son's hatred... turning Barry's otherwise initially victimized hero into a flawed anti-hero (where a road-ruse sequence involving Prussian captain Hardy Krüger is a standout)... and, ultimately, BARRY LYNDON becomes one of the most vile, unlikable villains in cinema history...Something only a narrowed and determined Ryan O'Neal could pull off so naturally, and without becoming a likeable rogue to keep the audience partially invested: especially during the heightened struggle with the vengeful stepson, now a teenager played by naive yet intense Leon Vitale, who, almost three-hours in, finally provides the movie a potential hero in what's actually an anti-epic epic, ironically centered on a title character hardly worth the time, which is the point all along and the kind of grand cinematic punchline even the biggest Kubrick fanatics initially missed, and why O'Neal's performance is often overlooked and misunderstood.

title: Relatively unknown jewel - Kubrick at his best?
content: It's only a couple of weeks ago that I saw Barry Lyndon for the first time. Though it was a relatively small TV screen I was stunned completely by - everything! I've never seen such marvelous acting, costumes, cut, music selection, camera etc.etc. brought together in a film. Just brilliant. Casting Barry Lyndon with American actor Ryan O'Neal is just a perfect choice. His accent doesn't disturb the movie, it enhances the experience, puts things in a perfect light. And, I loved the camera work, as well as the music selection. -- 18th century European court lifestyle --- that's just all right there.

title: A Dream of Sorrow
content: The meticulous award-winning recreation of 18th century Europe, the eye-watering beauty of this film, the opulence, the spectacle of it all is just the framing of a sad human story. The character of Redmond Barry is that of an innocent, but not helpless young man who will do whatever it takes to achieve a gentlemanly status -- and loses it all through his own ungentlemanly behavior. It's not easy to deal with Ryan O'Neal in this role. He does his best, and his commitment to it is obvious but, well, he's still Ryan O'Neal. But he is supported by a flawless cast, I can't begin to enumerate them. I particularly liked Murray Melvin as the parson who is so offended by, and jealous of, the studly young suitor of his patroness. This is a story that is paced in a stately manner, not "slow" or "static". It's thoughtful, it's meant to be looked at, it's a tragedy without a trace of irony. Once séen it is unforgettable.

title: barry lyndon
content: The frames and music of the film are excellent. The blue sky is reflected in the water, the castle on the green grass, the path in the forest, the dawn and dusk fog. Every scene is a beautiful landscape painting. The countess was pretty, though she did not play much part. Barry Linden is Love Story's Ryan O 'Neal, who has a kind, slightly bitter face, especially innocent eyes. Barry wasn't exactly the bad guy, at least in the moment when Viscount Brinton's gun went off in a duel. It was just fate. The whole film has a very classical charm, but the tempo is a bit slow. If there is enough time, it is still worth sitting down and watching.Remember my final conclusion: "All that happened in the time of George III, for better or for worse, for richer or for poorer, is now buried."

title: It feels like you are reading a book
content: Wonderful film.Visually stunning, music great.It feels like you are reading a book.Kubrick did a fantastic job as usual.

title: I cannot fathom this work of art!
content: Here's the thing: There's too much to talk about and I don't even know where to begin.(English accented voice) Suffice it to say, it's as perfect as a film gets. It does everything brilliantly well. And even though it's three hours long, it doesn't feel like it at all.And this is personally my second favorite Kubrick movie, right behind "A Clockwork Orange."

title: A beautiful work of Art
content: A couple of years ago I caught the end of a movie on TV that captivated for the brief time it was on.  Finally 2 years later I get the DVD.Initially the story was a bit slow, but nevertheless intriguing.  As the movie progress I got more and more drawn in.  Again Kubrick has done it, he doesn't use the camera by zooming in and out and using slow motions etc, he is able to simply set up a scene with detail and perfection then let the actors do the rest.Everyone complains that books to film never works.  Often the reason is trying to emphasise the emotion and thought process that takes place is very easy in a book, but very hard on film.  Kubrick just added narration and got the actors to not over-act and it worked perfectly.I could go on and on, but it's been said before.I imagine a lot will say this film is long and boring and it has no story. The reason is we're all conditioned to be told who the good guys are, who's right and wrong.  This is not the case we don't feel for the main character until the scene with his son (which was so well done).This has lots of similarities to 2001, lots of meticulous detail, lots of silences and subtleties.  As in 2001, this is more than a film, it is a work of art and should be experienced rather than just watched.

title: Bildingsroman - The development of Character
content: I was sitting drinking with a friend one night talking about movies, art and literature after a Werner Herzog Q&A following the premiere of his "Little Dieter wants to Fly" at the Roxie when the topic of Stanley Kubrik came up. We both instantly agreed he belongs in the pantheon of the movie gods."What's your favorite Kubrik movie" he asked."I know all the Kubrik fans and the critics hated it, but for me it's Barry Lyndon hands down." I replied.Long story slightly shortened, he agreed wholeheartedly and pulled out a copy from his shelf saying, "It's the only one I own." Most people are Kubrik fans for the spectacle of the extreme from films like Clockwork Orange and 2001 - brilliant in their own right - but never get beyond that to the essence of Kubrik - Character Development. Yeah I know, it's the bla bla bla the critics whine about being missing all the time, but that's what makes a movie, not the exploding cars.Barry Lyndon is all about the development of the character of a country Casanova becoming a lord and how his times shaped his character, much in the same way Clockwork Orange is about how language shapes our character.The Bildungsroman - or Character Development Novel - is most often cited as a German development attributed to Goethe and supposedly culminating with Thomas Mann, but the focus on the development of regular people was the major theme of 19th Century European Literature from Stendahlto Dostoyevsky all the way back as far as I can trace it to Shakespeare, Homer or the stories of Cuchullain - and most certainly Thackery and his contemporaries from Charles Dickens to Jane Austin.From Path's to Glory, Spartacus, on to the his last Kubrik is all about character -- even 2001 is strictly focused on the development of human character from the screeching ape to the dying aristocrat in his bed. (When even the development of a computer's character is a theme we are really expected to get the picture of what this is all about.) But he took it to the limit with this one, focusing over three hours on character and boring the action junkies, who were still on the Clockwork Orange horrorshow high, to death.But for myself and for many others this one is his greatest masterpieces because of that focus on character development. I would really like to see a previous poster explain what contemporary have film plots less "thin" than this.

title: 18th century is flat in England, nothing happens, how can you make something really significant to happen then in reality?
content: As a director, all genres are there to be picked. Whether you follow the standard of them all or step forward to challenge yourself in creating the ULTIMATE experience of whichever you choose to film about. Psychology of what characters would really say if they were real so to link them to us mortal viewers. Now, depicting an era requires, in the spirit of sincerity and simplicity, showing HOW IT REALLY WAS. Perhaps you'll start hating what you're doing since it will be simply hated by action movie consumers (a big majority of moviegoers) , but it is YOUR creation, and it just matters that you're in the genre doing it. The particularity about "Barry Lyndon" is that the story is nothing but reminiscent of the period. But how rich and outstanding was that time's music and paintings, yet their lives were so insignificant to us now. All about fighting irrelevant wars and going against your enemy countries for stupid and lucrative reasons... Depicting normal life requires not adding more than it is, true face value. We may add all the elements of today's movies in order to make this story super exciting, but then it would be again away from how it really was. People had to lit the candles for staying up during night, and life was tremendously BORING without internet and electricity and... Wait, when we see the movie we remove all these four centuries, again, we're trapped in boredomness, even though people lived in that way by that time. Period. From the bottom of our smartphones, Did we forget that we were humans? Was really Kubrick right in stating that we would be tech consumers totally immersed in talking with machines? Without technology we're living beings. Out of the life of going to school and studying in order to get a career, without any purpose in life, we make mistakes after mistakes, try again and again to reach our goals even when they're not the real goals from the spirit, spend our time in meaningless activities... In few words, "Barry Lyndon" shows us how was life before this post industrial revolution era. Perhaps you will say I'm not speaking about the movie at all, but, for the sake of valuing this movie, it really requires that we simply focus on WHAT IS IT TO MAKE A QUINTESSENTIAL MOVIE OF ITS ONE AND ONLY GENRE, or the different genres that it may englobe or represent.It doesn't really matters if the viewers like it or not, the way it is made and the whole resources that were used and the quality of all the elements put together. "Barry Lyndon" really reset the standard on how this genre had to be depicted, and how tremendously boring are period movies again! But how fascinating is liberating ourselves from this era, experiencing something that's not us.Honestly, the mixture of painting-like scenes with the mesmerizing music, the costumes and the candle-lit scenarios is the only thing that really helps digest these 3 hours of bittersweet and saddening dialogues. The result made the Academy speak and say: this is true grand filmmaking at its purest state, despite the boredomness again!The appreciation of culture only appears when we pay attention to what is done in the culture itself, no matter how insipid it was. If people from that era would manage to see this movie they would say: Kubrick, come here to our age and delight us because your time's people don't appreciate you at all! A few ones still do it. And counting... Dare me to say there are more than it appears.Despite what the audience may think, a movie belongs to its director, it's his/her creation. Perhaps people who speak about movies are eclipsed on what Kubrick did simply because he dedicated himself to simply create movies that, after 60 years still generate ardent debates over if we like them or not. People in the cinema industry keep talking and talking, and in the meantime, If you, moviegoer, truly appreciate music, paintings, culture and real life style of a specific era at its splendor, then "Barry Lyndon" is the movie for you. If action, speed and rollercoaster emotions suit you, still take a seat and you decide to give it two stars or take a step forward into reviewing it for how IT really is.Watching reality with Kubrick is really painful and rewarding at times. And this movie is not the exception at all. Taste it and enjoy it. You'll love it or hate it. Get to see what's beneath. Kubrick is tremendously impartial in all his filmography. Symmetry and order: Kubrickian doctrine. A 50/50 bet that will never end, or will it? A duel that starts and ends the same way. And again, every review is totally valid. But review, please! Opinions are immensely important. This is a BEAUTIFUL MOVIE!

title: One of my all time favorites
content: This has the most well developed characters of any Kubrick film. It is hilarious spell-binding beautiful and of course tragic. The dichotomy between surface level civility/decorum and primal brutality is exquisite. The casting is top notch. Barry stumbles his way to the top, and that very same ambition becomes his undoing in the end. Lord Bullingdon comes off very sympathetic as an innocent bystander of Barry's social climbing. The ending was perfect and the epilogue was the cherry on top, a simple yet eloquent statement that we are equal in death. There are no true villains or heroes in this journey. Yet in life, everyone is defined by their birth status, despite how hard Barry tries to rise above it. This film is endlessly rewatchable and a true masterpiece.

title: An exciting tragedy
content: It's a Kubrick's movie and that is enaught for descripiting as a masterpiece.A travel in the lifetime of a man with his dreams, emotions, stranghts and weaknesses. Every scenes and dialogues are perfectly curated.Kubrick is one of the best director of all time. As others his movies, Barry London must be absolutely watched.

title: As long as LotR, but no magic or Orcs
content: This 3hr1minute melodrama, is the story of a foolish country-boy who becomes a rich traveler, and then becomes a poor soldier, then an army deserter, then a poor soldier again, then a spy, then a double-agent, then a card-hustler, then the husband of a Lady, then a poor divorcee and finally a card-hustler once again...It's a story that has action, drama, romance, comedy and adventure all rolled into one movie, as it follows the story of a fellow named Barry.It's not a movie that I'd ever rewatch again tbh, but I'm happy that I watched it once.

title: Note that this is a Stanley piece , meaning it's not for everyone.
content: Everything about this film is perfect, except I felt something was missing in the second half and i don't know why to give this journey a 5 shinny stars!

title: this was okay
content: I usualy like two types of movies,movies about the old world like this one, and modern space epics like star wars and star trek. and this one falls under the same catagory as films like "The Man in the Iron Mask" or "The Patriot", only thing is that those films are much better than this one.- however this is one of the most beautifuly cinematography in a movie that I ever seen,Ddespite the Bazaar way this film plays out. I dont believe any film has ever captured the feel of the late 1700's better than this film did. the costumes are great,and sets are perfect. I also liked the whole natural light method in which this film was made.And the story is set into 2 halves, the first half is the rise Redmon Barry, and the 2nd half is the fall of Barry Lyndon(who are the same person)I even liked the narration of this film(I normaly despise narration- but the narration worked perfect for this film). This is a very classy film, and all of the actors did an outstanding job.(BTW:this film won 4 oscars). I reccomend this film, -you may or may not like it(I liked it but will also admit that other films in this same genre will blow it away -I found it interesting that a box set was released in 2000 with all of Kubrick's films in it- but this one(Barry Lyndon)was the only Kubrick film not in the box set. Kubrick knew that this film couldn't stand up to other films in this genre which is why he called it a failure-He believed at the time he was filming it that this was going to be his "Gone With the Wind" sweeping epic that would be endured for all times - and it never became that). This film also has one of the most unusual music scores I ever heard,the only way to describe the music in this film is wierd.But If you really liked this film you need to See "Bernard Cornwell's Sharpe Series," any of the A&E "Horatio Hornblower" movies or "The Patriot"(Starring Mel Gibson)because after seeing truely great movies like those, you will soon forget about Barry Lyndon. I will give it 3 out of 5 stars -Its still a much underated good movie

title: Beautiful and striking in detail and performance.
content: I was a fan of the work of Stanley Kubrick for roughly four years before I came upon this brilliant movie.  I had seen period pieces such as Dangerous Liaisons" and "Amadeus" before "Barry Lyndon," but I was in awe at the beauty and detail of the costumes and scenery.

title: Not as bad as I remember, but not as good as I wish.
content: I always dread rewatching Barry Lyndon. I tend to think of it as a weak film, more focused on cinematic gimmicks than intriguing story. I am bothered by all the reverse zoom shots, verite shots, freeze frames, candlelit scenes, Irish dances, and dirge overtures. Ryan O'Neil is a Dick Van Dyke Irishman with no emotional range. Marissa Berenson is a beautiful tangle of wigs. Leon Vitalli is the homeliest antagonist I've ever seen.But the years have mellowed me. O'Neil is still terrible, but I am finding nuances in his performance that keep me staring intensely. Berenson is still beautiful, but the deadpan expressions reveal a stoic personality and tragic character that stirs emotion. The camerawork is dated, but Kubrick's canvas is vast and stunning.I have a great deal more empathy for O'Neil's Barry. I see his life struggle like my own, full of adventure humor, and tragedy, as he works his way up the ladder of success. And he is successful. Barry even finishes life well off. Bullingdon makes good on a promise.What is unspoken is that the Narrator is unreliable. He sets the expectation that Barry is a cad and an imposter. We see Barry's bad habits, but we see he is good, too. He apologizes to his wife for his infidelity. He confesses over his desertions and Irish feelings. He canes Bullingdon, but rather gently and with good reason. He spares Bullingdon when he doesn't half to.So, far from being a woeful tale of tragedy and ruin, Barry Lyndon, reveals a life well-lived and almost brought to ruin, not by Barry's mistakes and greed, but by conniving people seeking to bring him down.As with any Kubrick film, you have to slow down and think about what you are seeing. There are many complexities and many levels, even in beautiful film like Barry Lyndon.

title: Young rogue Irishman
content: The movie; Infinity is a unique and masterpiece. Deep and narrative based on narrative. The narrator takes the viewer to the depths of the story, as if we were with Redmond along with his story. And in critical moments, our teacher reminds us of pure pleasure in cinema. What do we want from a masterpiece film? The story, the narrative, the epic, the love, the tragedy, the joy of life, and ultimately the salvation, all of which can be found in this Barry Lyndon.

title: Cult Movies 48
content: 48. BARRY LYNDON. adventure-drama, 1975: Ambitious but naive, Barry (RyanO'Neil) is determined to gain a higher place in 17th-century European society. However, his hot-tempered manner gets him into trouble early in life when a loveless romance ends in tragedy. Forced to flee his home, he enlists in the British army. Deserting, he finds success with a shrewd cardsharper that takes him under his wing. At last, having dispelled the notions of love and mastering the disguise of a 'gentleman', he courts the Countess of Lyndon (Marisa Berenson). They marry and he inherits her vast wealth, along with great troubles.Critique: Stanley Kubrik's overlong, ambitious epic stopped a run of critical and commercial hits (that started with 'The Killing'(1956). Kubrik's forte has always rested on his thematic storytelling and eccentric camera-work. Though intricately plotted and lavishly produced, the film suffers from these same excesses.The first 'part' of the film is a complete bore, without any of Kubrik's wit and imagination. However, it is considerably lifted when the lovely Marisa Berenson appears as the Countess of Lyndon. Her courting scene is one of the most hypnotic, expertly filmed sequences in cinema history.The rest of the performances are adequate at best, and Kubrik's vision is still wonderful to watch. The music (as in every Kubrik film) is beautifully resonant. The film's slow pace and artistic excesses by Kubrick, makes it not for all tastes.QUOTES: Narrator: "The doctors were called. But what does a doctor avail in the contest with the grim, Invincible enemy."

title: Paintings Didn't Come To Life, Life Came Into Paintings.
content: This is simply a masterpiece. Each of Kubrick's film has a statement about humanity and life. Barry Lyndon is not the exception. In fact, I think this is the most powerful statement made by Kubrick, no, by movies! Never before nor after did a film express how a life can change so much trough time and how other value your life has it changes because of your surroundings. It expressed that selfishness can destroy other peoples lives, the power of forgiveness, the sadness of death. It also expressed the passage of time on each and every human being, having lived a wealthy life or not, being selfish or not, no matter our age that death can reach everyone of us and that we should live our life in the best way possible. Those are only Kubrick's work. The acting was incredible! Some of the actors didnt say a word for the intire movie and still made us understand all the emotions that they where going through. It is also one of the best looking movie of all time, some people even describe it has an animations of painting. The music, was incredible, all those classic music pieces joined together made an ocean of emotions. This is certainly the most powerful movie anyone can see, it has absolutely no flaws, it is awesome in its own way and I think its closest you will ever get to understand Stanley Kubrick's genius.

title: one word: beautiful!
content: I began to be a fan of Mr. Kubrick last year, and ever since, I've constantly tried to get my hands on every film he's done.The cinematography is the most beautiful I've ever seen, next to Gone with the Wind.  The acting was tight, and generally very well done.  The adapted period music sounded great to the ear.  And the story, I found very interesting.  To me, there is a moral to this fine story by Thackery.  If you are given somthing good, don't screw everything up by taking advantage of it, or being greedy.  Though the film was very long, I, myself, did not find it boring.  (My mother fell asleep through some of it, yet she loved the story line.  And she doesn't even like long movies like Barry Lyndon.) This film can be overlooked by young fans of Mr. Kubrick, and it is a shame, because this is amongst his greatest triumphs.

title: Visual Masterpiece
content: Truly a visual masterpiece by Kubrick. The movie is one of the most visually amusing/satisfying movies and the score really set the mood with the costumes and the musical pieces.However, the story was kinda dull/boring and characters were cold and emotionless. The movie in that sense didn't strike me! I honestly think if any other director did the same movie he wouldn't get praised like Kubrick in this movie. Yes this movie is GREAT but not as much as people are hyping it. To be a great movie every single aspect has to be a "Masterpiece", not just the costumes and cinematography.Th movie is visually stunning. It's like every shot by Kubrick is a classical painting. I was fascinated that he used a lenses developed by NASA to shoot in low light, The use of wide shots, symmetry, and slow zooms further enhances the film's experience!!A true cinematic masterpiece.The movies' costumes, sets was surprising and very authentic.. it really set me in that period.This dedication to make such a historic movie realistically accurate allowed the audience to experience history as it was. (in that period)What I really noticed and enjoyed very much was the score! It really set the mood and shaped the tone emotionally! It's very elegant.However! I didn't like it to the point that it's a complete masterpiece and one of the greatest movies ever! Why?::The slow pace as i feel kubrick concentrated more on atmosphere and visual composition over traditional dramatic plot.Also the characters felt emotionally detached . It was very hard for me as a viewer to connect with them! Even barry!At first he was ambitious and a loving person l! Then a terrible person who you couldn't feel any compassion too..Even Lady Lyndon was very rigid (maybe reflected the era she was in depending on her class). Anyways they were very cold and detached. Their acting didn't let me feel anything for them or the movieAs I said, Kubrick i feel depended on visuals rather than words. Story very boring a dull. First part was interesting, built a sense of adventure. Then the second part was the decline of Barry Lyndon (as an aristocrat).Also Why the hell did he let him shoot his leg?Anyways, enjoyed it visually the cinematography, directing, costumes and even score. But the story and characters were very dull and cold and the storyline was not very interesting.

title: The best ever? Well, ...
content: ... probably not, but still a ten. Photography is luscious. Costumes and sets are other worldly. Pacing is excruciatingly slow, however. All those set this film In a class of very, very few.Absolutely recommended by me as well as the Academy.

title: Kubrick
content: In one word, its a Kubrick. Perfection in every frame, strong ark, nice cast. The one and characters are a bit sterile but was intentional. Same for main char. A bit doll like but that was exactly the point. Art direction, idea shown and subtle humor is on unreachable levels.

title: Truly, every frame is a painting
content: This film shows the tale of the eponymous Barry Lyndon, the antihero of Irish origins trying to make his way in the aristocracy. It's a truly epic film with a sprawling runtime and methodical pace. From the very beginning, we see his impulsive and tempestuous character running into deep conflict with everyone around him, a theme repeated many times in his life. Another big theme we encounter is Barry's opportunistic trickery, used to escape the army, scam gamblers out of money and suck the Lyndon estate dry. These are portrayed in lingering scenes that resemble paintings, showing the reactions and thoughts of everyone in a way that allows for visual contemplation.

title: The life of a boring nobody
content: Three solid hours of style over substance, elaborate costumes, and closeups of pensive faces, an exercise in lighting and camera angles and wood paneled interiors, all could have been better served to showcase a main character who actually accomplished something significant, but instead we get an intimate look at an average Joe, played by an average Joe. What does it all mean? There is no meaning. The Shining=haunted house. 2001=a statement about humanity. Dr. Strangelove=the cold war. The Killing=heist film. Barry Lyndon=???? Ryan O'Neal is woefully miscast, it's actually painful to watch him struggling to keep up with more accomplished actors, I notice that none of the ten-star reviews defend his awful performance and accent.
